articles.title: New V-level courses to be brought in for students after GCSEs
articles.summary: Ministers say new vocational courses will simplify the "confusing" options students have after GCSEs.
articles.content:
New V-level courses to be brought in for students after GCSEs

6 hours ago Share Save Hazel Shearing Education correspondent Share Save

Getty Images

New vocational courses called V-levels will be rolled out for 16-year-olds under government plans to simplify a "confusing landscape" of qualifications in England. They are set to replace Level 3 BTecs and other post-16 technical qualifications. Ministers also plan to reduce the number of teenagers resitting maths and English GCSEs by introducing an alternative qualification. The Sixth Form Colleges Association warned that V-levels may not fill the gap left by BTecs. Ministers are expected to lay out proposals for higher education funding, including university tuition fees, on Monday afternoon.

The government has launched a consultation on its V-level plans, which form part of its post-16 education and skills white paper. They come after Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer stressed the importance of vocational training, announcing a target for two-thirds of young people to go to university or study a technical qualification. Lola Marshall, 17, hopes to do an apprenticeship after her health and social care extended diploma at Leeds City College, and said there wasn't enough discussion about vocational routes at school. "Everyone always talked about university and no one ever really helped me decide whether I wanted to do university or an apprenticeship," she said.

BBC/ Hope Rhodes Lola says alternative vocational options were not discussed much when she was at school

It is not yet clear when V-levels will be introduced, how they will be rolled out, or which subjects will be on offer - although the Department for Education (DfE) gave craft and design and media, broadcast and production as examples. Skills minister Baroness Jacqui Smith said V-levels aimed to simplify options for students. "There are over 900 courses at the moment that young people have the choice of, and it's confusing," she said. "[V-levels] will build on what's good about BTecs and other alternative qualifications - the ability to be able to work practically, the concentration on things that are going to lead to employment." Students will still be able to study A-levels or T-levels after their GCSEs, or start an apprenticeship. Ministers expect many will want to mix and match between A-levels and V-levels. T-levels, introduced in 2020, already offer a technical route for students, but the initial findings of a government-commissioned review said they shouldn't be the only option, partly because of their high entry requirements. Students study one T-level geared towards a specific occupation, whereas they might study three A-levels in different subjects. Baroness Smith said T-levels therefore suited students who "really know that's what [they] want to do", while V-levels would be better for those who were less sure.

Plans to scrap BTecs have been under way for a few years, and campaigners have stressed the importance of students having an alternative to A-levels and T-levels. Bill Watkin, chief executive of the Sixth Form Colleges Association, said students must be able to enrol on BTecs and other courses for the next two years. "While the detail has yet to be established, there is a risk that the new V-levels will not come close to filling the gap that will be left by the removal of applied general qualifications," he said. David Hughes, the chief executive of the Association of Colleges, said V-levels might bring more "clarity and certainty" to further education. "We've seen before lots of attempts to raise the profile of vocational and technical learning – we've got to hope this time we get it right as a nation," he said.

Baroness Smith also said a new qualification would be introduced as an alternative to GCSE resits, helping students who "too often have been on this demoralising roundabout of taking exams and failing them". In England, pupils who don't get at least a grade 4 in GCSE English and maths have to continue studying for it alongside their next course, and are expected to resit. However, the resit pass rate is low and the policy has proved controversial. The government said offering an alternative would "break down barriers to opportunity", because white working class pupils were twice as likely to need to resit than their better-off classmates. Its white paper will also propose that teenagers are offered a choice of two "pathways" - one focused on study and one on work - which will set out which qualifications they'll need to achieve their goals.
articles.reasoning: The introduction of new V-level vocational courses aims to simplify and improve post-GCSE education options, providing clearer, practical pathways for a broad range of students and potentially reducing the need for GCSE resits. This policy has the potential to positively impact many young people across England by offering more accessible and relevant qualifications, addressing educational inequalities, and supporting employment outcomes.
articles.personality_title: New V-level courses to simplify education choices after GCSEs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In England, students who finish their GCSE exams at age 16 face many options for further study. These include A-levels, T-levels, BTecs, and other technical courses. The variety can be confusing, and some students struggle with resitting GCSEs in English and maths.

**What happened** – The government plans to introduce new vocational courses called V-levels to replace Level 3 BTecs and similar qualifications. These courses aim to offer clearer, more practical options for students after their GCSEs. V-levels will focus on skills that lead to jobs and allow students to mix them with A-levels if they want. The government is also working on a new qualification to replace GCSE resits in English and maths, which many students find difficult to pass.

**Impact** – V-levels could make it easier for students to choose courses that match their interests and career goals. Unlike T-levels, which are specialized and require high entry levels, V-levels will suit students who are still exploring their options. This change could help reduce the number of students stuck repeating GCSE exams and offer fairer chances for those from less wealthy backgrounds.

**What's next step** – The government is currently asking for opinions on the V-level plans and will share more details soon, including which subjects will be offered and when the courses will start. They will also present ideas about funding for higher education and university fees. Schools, colleges, and students will watch closely to see how these new courses develop.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New V-level courses aim to make post-GCSE education simpler and more practical, helping more students find pathways that suit their skills and future jobs.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouveaux cours V-level pour simplifier les choix après les GCSE
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Angleterre, les élèves de 16 ans qui terminent leurs examens GCSE ont plusieurs options pour continuer leurs études, comme les A-levels, T-levels, BTecs et autres formations techniques. Ce choix est souvent compliqué, et certains élèves doivent repasser les GCSE en anglais et maths.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le gouvernement prévoit de lancer de nouveaux cours professionnels appelés V-levels pour remplacer les BTecs de niveau 3 et d'autres qualifications similaires. Ces cours veulent offrir des choix plus clairs et pratiques après les GCSE. Les V-levels se concentreront sur des compétences utiles pour trouver un emploi et permettront aux élèves de les combiner avec les A-levels. Le gouvernement prépare aussi une nouvelle qualification pour remplacer les repêchages des GCSE en anglais et maths, souvent difficiles à réussir.

**Impact** – Les V-levels pourraient faciliter le choix des élèves en leur proposant des cours adaptés à leurs intérêts et projets professionnels. Contrairement aux T-levels, qui sont spécialisés et demandent un bon niveau pour entrer, les V-levels conviendront à ceux qui cherchent encore leur voie. Cela pourrait aussi réduire le nombre d’élèves qui doivent repasser les GCSE et offrir plus d’égalité pour les jeunes issus de milieux moins favorisés.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement consulte actuellement sur les plans des V-levels et donnera bientôt plus de détails, notamment sur les matières proposées et la date de lancement. Il présentera aussi ses idées sur le financement de l’enseignement supérieur et les frais universitaires. Les écoles, collèges et élèves suivront attentivement l’évolution de ces nouveaux cours.

**En une phrase** – Les nouveaux cours V-level veulent rendre l’éducation après les GCSE plus simple et pratique, aidant plus d’élèves à trouver des parcours adaptés à leurs compétences et à leur avenir.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevos cursos V-level para simplificar las opciones tras los GCSE
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Inglaterra, los estudiantes de 16 años que terminan sus exámenes GCSE tienen muchas opciones para continuar sus estudios, como A-levels, T-levels, BTecs y otros cursos técnicos. Estas opciones pueden resultar confusas, y algunos estudiantes deben repetir los GCSE de inglés y matemáticas.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno planea introducir nuevos cursos vocacionales llamados V-levels para reemplazar los BTecs de nivel 3 y otras cualificaciones similares. Estos cursos buscan ofrecer opciones más claras y prácticas después de los GCSE. Los V-levels se centrarán en habilidades útiles para encontrar empleo y permitirán a los estudiantes combinarlos con A-levels si lo desean. También están trabajando en una nueva cualificación para reemplazar las repeticiones de los GCSE en inglés y matemáticas, que muchos estudiantes encuentran difíciles de aprobar.

**Impacto** – Los V-levels podrían facilitar que los estudiantes elijan cursos que se adapten a sus intereses y objetivos profesionales. A diferencia de los T-levels, que son especializados y tienen altos requisitos de entrada, los V-levels serán mejores para quienes aún no están seguros de qué quieren hacer. Este cambio podría ayudar a reducir el número de estudiantes que repiten exámenes GCSE y ofrecer oportunidades más justas para jóvenes de entornos menos favorecidos.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno está consultando sobre los planes de los V-levels y pronto dará más detalles, incluyendo qué materias se ofrecerán y cuándo comenzarán los cursos. También presentará propuestas sobre la financiación de la educación superior y las tasas universitarias. Escuelas, colegios y estudiantes estarán atentos para ver cómo avanzan estos nuevos cursos.

**Una frase resumen** – Los nuevos cursos V-level buscan hacer la educación post-GCSE más simple y práctica, ayudando a más estudiantes a encontrar caminos que se adapten a sus habilidades y trabajos futuros.
